title:
Contact and bulk rectification effects in ferromagnetic resonance
  experiments
authors: Md. Majibul Haque Babu and Maxim Tsoi
abstract:
We present an experimental study of the spin rectification effects produced
by ferromagnetic resonance in a NiFe wire. A system of four independent
nonmagnetic contact probes was used to supply both rf and dc currents to the
wire and to measure dc voltages at different locations in the wire. The rf
current drives the ferromagnet's magnetization into resonance and produces a dc
photovoltage which results from the rectification of rf current in the
ferromagnet with oscillating magnetization. Our 4-probe system provided a means
to detect the photovoltage and separate contributions from the
ferromagnet/nonmagnet contacts and the bulk of the ferromagnet. The contact
photovoltage was found to increase approximately linearly with the dc bias
applied to the wire. In contrast, the bulk contribution was found to be almost
independent of the dc bias. By tuning properties of individual contact probes
we were able to change the magnitude of the contact photovoltage and even
reverse its sign. Our results highlight the different contributions to
photovoltage and the importance of contact properties/nonlinearities for
rectification effects in spintronic devices.
